attributes.title: Children Are Giving Cable TV And Cinemas A Miss And This Is Bad News For Both Hasbro And Mattel
summary: Half of Mattel’s and Hasbro’s business is driven by films on Cable or big-screen movie houses.
About half the below 11-year-old consumer group no longer watches Cable TV. A similar percentage applies to Cinemas.
They have moved over to streaming services which do not feature current films and which mostly do not allow advertising.
Disney’s buying Fox and getting control of Hulu may rescue Hasbro from this trap and this is likely to give it a major competitive advantage over Mattel.
In any event, the entire toy industry is in for a very rough ride between the shift from brick-and-mortar retail to online on one side and from traditional TV and Cinema to streaming on the other.

attributes.content:
The traditional entertainment space for children in the U.S. is declining rapidly and this leaves both Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) and Mattel (NASDAQ:MAT) facing massive technological change.

Firstly, a few facts:

  • Nearly half of Hasbro’s business is driven by movies – either on the big screen or on Cable TV. This includes most of its Action Figures but also Disney (DIS) Princess, Pony, Sesame and a fair portion of its Board Game business.
  • In the case of Mattel, we are looking at more than half of its business being driven by Cable TV and virtually nothing by big screen movies.

The problem is that both media – big screen movies and Cable TV series – are in the U.S. in decline in terms of audience participation and the rest of the world is following the U.S. lead.

In the case of traditional TV, this decline applies to all age groups below the 50-year-olds. The drop in the typical toy generation, the 1 to 11-year-olds, this decline is 22% in the six years between 2010 and 2016 and there is nothing to suggest that this decline has not continued since then:

If this was not bad enough, the worse news is that the same age group is also spending less time in front of the goggle box:

Source: U.S. Nielsen

What this adds up to is that half of the core toy consumer – the child – has walked away from watching TV.

Big-screen movies are not doing much better. Overall attendance has been declining since 2003:

Source: U.S. Nielsen

Within this decline, the movie categories typically catering to the below 11-year-old age group – the PG and PG13 rated films - are also doing badly:

Source: Box Office Mojo

So, the first question is – with both Cinemas and Cable TV stations losing customers, what is going on?

In the case of TV, there is this animal called a cord-cutter. It is the consumer who is sick and tired of paying through his or her nose to watch a lot of drivel mixed with equally bad commercials. He or she is moving away from cable and is going to streaming providers such as Netflix (NFLX), which offers the choice of being able to see what you want to see, when you want to see it and this without commercials.

In addition, there are all the newcomers – consumers who have never even bothered to watch traditional TV. This is how the trend developed for both groups since 2016:

UBS took another crack at the same subject – they estimated how many viewers traditional TV providers lost between 2012 and 2016 and how many Streaming TV gained in the same time span:

You can assume that it was the adults in the household who took the decision to cut the cord, or never to tie it, and that the children of the family just went with the flow.

In the case of Cinemas, there is the individual who just stays at home and watches his or her preferred movies from their couch and you can assume that the kids in this household do exactly the same:

In both cases, the clear winners are the Streaming Services.

According to Internet World Stats, the U.S. had on 6/30/2017 an internet user population of 286.9 million, which equals 88% of the total population. ComScore on 4/10/2017 and Ad Age on 1/9/2018 estimated the number of streaming subscribers at 146 million, broken down as follows amongst the top five Streaming Services:

Company

Number of Subscribers

U.S. Market Share

Netflix

53 million

36.30%

YouTube/Google

31 million

21.23%

DirecTV/AT&T

25 million

17.12%

Amazon

20 million

13.70%

Hulu/Fox

17 million

11.65%

Total

146 million

100.00%

What does this mean for Mattel and Hasbro?

It means that their main drivers – be that big screen movies or films aired on Cable TV – are losing core toy consumers – the kids – at an accelerating rate. This would not matter if the same kids were again picked up at the Streaming Services but this is not the case.. None of the current blockbusters are being shown on Streaming Services – no Last Jedi, no Justice League, no Thor Ragnarok, no Transformers The Last Knight, and no Spiderman Homecoming 2. The same applies to Cable TV Series – no Star Wars Rebels, no Marvel Spiderman, no Guardians, no Tangled or Elena of Avalor.

Yes, the Streaming Services do show toy-related films but just not those that help Mattel or Hasbro. Amazon (AMZN) shows Sesame Street, Dora and Lego Star Wars; Hulu carries Sesame Street. Netflix shows a ton of Disney movies but just not those released last year. If you talk to national buyers at the large retailers, they will tell you that the toy-draw today of 2016 movies or earlier ones is minimal.

The toy companies could of course counteract all this by shifting advertising dollars to the Streaming Services. There is only one problem with this. Netflix does not accept ads. Hulu, YouTube (GOOG) (GOOGL) and Amazon offer ad-free services and these are growing much more rapidly than the ad-offering variety. DirecTV (T) has only ad-versions now but is apparently considering the non-ad version as well. The reason for this is simple. Parents tend to dislike ads directed at children. The American Psychological Association had the following to say on the subject:

The more fundamental concern regarding the effects of advertising on children relates to questions of potential harm resulting from exposure. A variety of research findings are relevant to this issue. Several studies, for example, have found that parent–child conflicts occur commonly when parents deny their children's product purchase requests that were precipitated by advertising.

According to GeekWire, Netflix, and other services with kid-specific offerings like Amazon Video and Hulu, make it much easier for parents to control their kids’ entertainment options. They offer an easy way to keep a child entertained with no commercial interruption.

This leaves the Toy industry in a real quandary because with films becoming less of a driver, advertising becomes more important. Statista quantified this in a chart given below:

Leading toys and games-related products advertised on TV in the United States in the 4th quarter 2017, by number of occurrences:

There is another factor that has a bearing on this – is TV advertising still worth doing? According to Steve Byrne in his book “A Profile of the United States Toy Industry, Second Edition: Serious Fun” this is debatable. He says that

“And there is another issue to consider: return of investment. When scheduled TV was the dominant medium reaching children, the advertising to sales ration was tremendous. The general rule of thumb was that for every dollar spend on advertising, it was possible to forecast 20 dollars in sales. Today, this number is significantly less, coming in about 5 dollars for every dollar spent.”

So, what is a toy manufacturer to do? One way is of course to go back to the basics and to rely less on films and TV advertising to do your job and more on own innovation. There are a great many products out there that do incredibly well because they are new, and fresh, and different. Hatchimals, LOL, Enchantimals, Fingerlings, P J Masks, MC2, JoJo Siwa and Roblox come to mind. They are not simply plastic replicas of movie actors or old tired Barbies in a new pair of shoes but are genuinely the end result of an incredible creative effort.

The other avenue is to change the fundamental model. This is what Disney is trying to do in its acquisition of Fox, which gives it control over Hulu. It lets Disney yank all its films from Netflix by 2019 and move them over to Hulu. By doing so, Disney will have the choice of airing all the newest Disney and Fox blockbusters not only in Cinemas and Cable TV but also on its own Streaming Service. This will then give Hasbro, as the probable licensee of all this great movie IPs, a solid entry into the Streaming world – an entry which neither they nor Mattel have today.

This, unfortunately, leaves Mattel out in the cold and at a very significant competitive disadvantage. The company will face essentially two choices. It can either try to get more Disney/Fox licenses similar to CARS and Avatar and so hitch a ride on Hulu or it can go back to basics and rely on product innovation to drive its business.

One thing is for certain. The toy industry is in for a very rough ride. Between the accelerating shift from brick-and-mortar stores to online retail, and from Cinemas and Cable TV to Streaming services, the relatively placid world in which toy manufacturers now live is undergoing fundamental change. It will be interesting to see who is left standing at the end of this decade.

attributes.innerMarketing:
Get insider insights on the toy industry...

With more than three decades of insider experience as an executive in the toy industry, I have the ability to spot trends before they manifest, and discern key opportunities for investors. Join Business Intel on Toys and get exclusive, behind-the-scenes analysis, research and commentary you won't find anywhere else. Whether toys are your focus or a small portion of your portfolio, I can help you better understand the industry, the trends, their impact, and how to make the most of the opportunities to invest and create profits in this space.

attributes.bio:
Lutz is an acknowledged expert on the toy space. His clients include one of the top three U.S. banks and one of the top three non-public toy companies worldwide. Between 1984 and 2002, Lutz was the CEO at five different manufacturing companies catering to U.S. and international mass retailers. He's lived on five continents and speaks six languages.


He started his business intelligence consulting practice in 2003 and he derives his information from three primary sources. The first is his proprietary retailer panel, which includes Wal-Mart, Target, J C Penney, Kohl's, Gamestop, Dollar General, Barnes + Noble and Learning Express. This panel provides him with sell-through data, shelf space changes, inventory levels and other pertinent metrics governing the major companies and products active in the two industry categories. The second is national buyers at 30 leading retailers in 17 large country markets. These provide color on trends and issues that have a bearing on the major manufacturers and products in the two industry categories. The last is mainly Chinese third-party manufacturers who provide insights into supply and inventory issues affecting the major companies or products in the two industry categories.

Lutz consults with banks and hedge funds, and hence does not trade in any stocks associated with companies active in the spaces he focuses on. Lutz also is a monthly contributor to Seeking Alpha. He also publishes a monthly Toy Newsletter, which can be found on his website, www.klosterstrading.com.
